item.title: Covid: WHO scheme Covax delivers first vaccines
item.description: It is a milestone for the WHO scheme, which aims to ensure the fair distribution of Covid-19 jabs.

item.title: Summer catch-up schools planned for pupils in England
item.description: A total of £720m will help ensure "no child is left behind" due to the pandemic, Boris Johnson says.

item.title: Tiger Woods car crash: Golfing great 'awake and responsive' following surgery
item.description: Tiger Woods is "awake and responsive" following surgery on serious leg injuries suffered in a car crash in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell offers to give up UK and French citizenship for bail
item.description: The British socialite is in jail in New York awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges.

item.title: Covid: 150,000 more with learning disabilities to be prioritised for vaccine
item.description: It comes after DJ Jo Whiley's call for people like her sister to be vaccinated as soon as possible.

item.title: Fashion designer Alexander Wang accused of sexual assault
item.description: More allegations against the US designer emerge as a student speaks to BBC News.

item.title: Rape social media posts: How speaking out got twin sisters sued
item.description: Twins Verity and Lucy were taken to court after speaking out on social media, naming their alleged abuser.

item.title: Syria's ex-intelligence officer convicted in landmark Germany case
item.description: A German court sentences Eyad al-Gharib to jail for complicity in crimes against humanity.

item.title: New Zealand: Rescuers save 28 whales from stranding spot
item.description: Rescuers have successfully refloated 28 pilot whales on a notorious New Zealand beach, Farewell Spit.

item.title: Heathrow passenger numbers fall to 1970s' levels
item.description: Covid "devastated" air travel in 2020, the UK's largest airport says, as it sinks to a £2bn loss.

item.title: 'I was often the only women in the room, that's changed'
item.description: Boards of big companies have 50% more women present than in 2015, a government review has found.

item.title: Apple buys a company every three to four weeks
item.description: The technology giant has bought around 100 companies in six years, chief executive Tim Cook has revealed.

item.title: The Papers: 'Faster path to freedom' and stamp duty 'to be extended'
item.description: Wednesday's front pages continue to focus on how the UK will emerge from lockdown.

item.title: Walker Swamp: The mission to restore an Australian wetland
item.description: Walker Swamp had been destroyed by 150 years of farming - now it is replenished and welcoming life.

item.title: IVF: How one single man hopes to become a father
item.description: Stephen Dyer says he will "do anything" to become a parent - including a bill of up to £40,000.

item.title: Covid: MP told to 'dress properly' for House of Commons debate
item.description: Jonathan Gullis was barred from speaking in the House of Commons until he had put on a jacket.

item.title: Bitcoin: Elon Musk loses world's richest title as Tesla falters
item.description: The Tesla chief's wealth has taken a hit as investors sour on Bitcoin and the electric carmaker.

item.title: Motera stadium: The world's largest cricket venue to host India-England Test
item.description: India's Motera stadium gives an unobstructed view of the pitch to 110,000 spectators.

item.title: Priyanka Dewan: The roller-skating star who beat disability stigma
item.description: Since taking up skating at the age of eight, Priyanka Dewan has become an international champion.

item.title: Senegal's teenage jockey races to fame
item.description: Fallou Diop won the country's top racing prize when he was just 17.

item.title: Attenborough gives stark warning on climate change to UN
item.description: Climate change could destroy "entire cities" in a matter of decades, says Sir David Attenborough.

item.title: Australia: Oldest rock art is 17,300-year-old kangaroo
item.description: Scientists determined the painting's age by examining ancient wasp nests around the artwork.

item.title: Covid tests and masks: School prepares for return to class
item.description: The BBC speaks to pupils, staff and parents at a school as they ready for in-person learning again.

item.title: Rescued orangutans returned to the wild
item.description: An Indonesian rehabilitation centre in Borneo has released 10 orangutans into the wild.

item.title: The Simpsons creator Matt Groening on equality, memes and monorails
item.description: BBC Radio 1 Newsbeat sits down for a Zoom chat with Matt Groening.

item.title: Tiger Woods: The triumphs and troubles of golf superstar
item.description: The man considered by many to be the greatest golfer of all time has overcome many challenges in his career.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'My billion pound company has no HR department'
item.description: Greg Jackson, founder and CEO of Octopus Energy, explains why he doesn't need a human resources team.

item.title: Budget 2021: Furloughed and unemployed – can Rishi help?
item.description: More support for jobs is expected in Chancellor Rishi Sunak's Budget, but will it be enough?

item.title: Does size matter for Britain's shrinking Army?
item.description: Brigadier John Clark says the British army will become "leaner", ahead of the defence review.

item.title: Creation Stories: Playing Liam and Noel Gallagher 'is a gift as an actor'
item.description: The young Gallaghers appear in Creation Stories - a film about Oasis's former label boss Alan McGee.

item.title: 'Super-agent' Raiola on Haaland, Pogba and football's future
item.description: 'Super-agent' Mino Raiola talks to BBC Sport about Erling Braut Haaland and Paul Pogba, plus the financial crisis in football.

item.title: Dating apps scam committed by criminal from inside prison
item.description: A recently reformed criminal shares how he ran romance scams to serve as a warning to others.

item.title: Lockdown exit plan: 'Why we can't wait to get back on the pitch'
item.description: With outdoor sport hopefully set to resume in March, Newsbeat hears about the importance of playing football.

item.title: Lennon resigns as Celtic manager with club 18 points behind Rangers
item.description: Celtic manager Neil Lennon resigns with his side 18 points adrift of Rangers in the Scottish Premiership.

item.title: Champions League: Why there is no need to fear another Man City mess-up - Micah Richards analysis
item.description: BBC pundit Micah Richards explains why he is no longer worried about what is going to go wrong for Manchester City in the Champions League.

item.title: LGBT+ History Month: Gareth Thomas on living with HIV - and dispelling its myths
item.description: Former British and Irish Lions rugby union captain Gareth Thomas describes being diagnosed with HIV as "petrifying" but is now using his profile to dispel myths around the virus.

item.title: 'It was the right decision' - Bayern's Musiala picks Germany over England
item.description: Jamal Musiala makes a big decision in opting to play for Germany over England and Nigeria at international level.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The prime minister has announced a plan for how the lockdown will be lifted in England.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday in the UK or travel abroad?
item.description: The government has unveiled its plans for unlocking UK restrictions, including holiday travel.

item.title: Covid: When will schools reopen?
item.description: All students in England can return to classrooms from 8 March as part of the plans to ease lockdown.

item.title: Will I still have to work at home? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will services like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Schools reopening: How at risk are children?
item.description: BBC's Health reporter Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: More people have been added to the clinically extremely vulnerable list in England. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Has the NHS got enough of the right PPE?
item.description: Who needs it - and does the UK health service have the right kit?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 16 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK, so when might you get one?

item.title: Is the Covid vaccine safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covax: How will Covid vaccines be shared around the world?
item.description: A scheme to distribute Covid-19 vaccines globally is under way. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of a new variant of Covid-19.

item.title: What is a challenge trial and why do we need them?
item.description: Some volunteers in the UK will be deliberately infected with coronavirus in a "challenge trial".

item.title: Covid: Claims vaccinations harm fertility unfounded
item.description: Social-media posts - some described as "scare stories" - are based on misunderstandings, experts say.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Covid: How will we know if the vaccine is working?
item.description: Deaths are falling faster for the over-80s - but does that mean the vaccine is working?

item.title: Netflix and Anna Delvey: The race to secure the story of New York's 'fake heiress'
item.description: How Anna Sorokin's life rights became hot property.
